conclusion: A coach bus is traveling at a constant speed of v = 20 m/s. Suddenly, the driver spots a puppy directly ahead at a distance of x = 45 m, and immediately applies the brakes. The time interval Δt between the driver seeing the puppy and the coach bus starting to decelerate uniformly in a straight line is 0.5s.
The velocity-time graph shows the bus traveling at 20 m/s from t = 0 to t = 0.5 s, then decelerating uniformly to 0 m/s at t = 5.0 s.

premise: During the 0.50 s “reaction time” the speed stays at 20 m/s.
conclusion: The bus travels d₁ = v Δt = (20 m/s)(0.50 s) = 10 m during the reaction time.

premise: After the reaction time, the velocity decreases uniformly from 20 m/s to 0 m/s in 4.5 s.
conclusion: The magnitude of the constant deceleration is a = (0 – 20 m/s)/(4.5 s) = –4.4 m/s².

premise: The distance covered while braking is the area of the right-triangle under the v–t graph.
conclusion: The distance covered while braking is d₂ = ½ (base) (height) = ½(4.5 s)(20 m/s) = 45 m.

premise: Total distance travelled before coming to rest is the sum of the distance during reaction time and braking.
conclusion: d_total = d₁ + d₂ = 10 m + 45 m = 55 m.

premise: Since 55 m > 45 m, the bus reaches the puppy’s position before stopping.
conclusion: No—the puppy is not safe; the bus would still be moving when it reaches the 45 m mark.
